ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about chemical properties and structures that are important in understand the science behind cooking.
The chemistry behind food and how the process of cooking and various reactions affects the outcome of it

I learned a lot about the molecules that make up food, what we are actually doing when we cook, and why we do it. This class was also a good refresher on scientific concepts I had not revisited since high school, like types of chemical bonds, the laws of thermodynamics, catalysis, transcription, translation, etc.
I learned chemistry from a very interesting and relatable perspective. Not only have I learned the basics of chemistry but also have developed a greater appreciation for cooking!
Many chemistry concepts that are applicable to daily life.

I gained critically important grounding in the basics of Chemistry. As a non-STEM major, I savored this chance to gain a more sophisticated understanding of the world from a scientific, rather than a historical, perspective!
I learned a lot of chemistry and how it is involved with food and cooking
Chem
The process and nature of cooking while also learning the underlying science of nutrition such as proteins,carbs, etc...
I learned a lot about chemistry, atoms, the way molecules interact, and different techniques of cooking.
I learned some basic elements of chemistry and know a lot more about the molecular structure of various foods and ingredients.
I gained a really good foundation of chemistry knowledge. I never took a true chemistry course and I thought this one taught chemistry in a really engaging way.

Chemical bonds regarding fats, proteins, sugar, and how they experience different phase changes in the presence of heat or lack of it. What reactions take place during cooking or other processes involving food. What makes food taste and feel the way it does.
General, basic understanding of Chemistry and its appliances geared towards processes of food and cooking
I learned basics of chemistry like thermodynamics, molecular motion, and molecular structures, all while connecting food concepts to them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Kind, understanding, and helpful professor and TFs. Easy concepts to understand 
Weaknesses: The in-class exercises were kinda annoying as they were given every lecture and sometimes we didn't have enough time or knowledge to answer the questions.

Strengths- insightful lectures and excellent professor
Weakness- some of the exercises did not seem important to the material/were a little overwhelming and hard to complete in time frame

I was not a fan of the many group exercises on Canvas because I have not found Zoom breakout rooms to be productive for learning. In addition, the frequency of them meant that if you missed even a single lecture, you were probably going to lose points towards the final grade with no way of making up for them. However, I did appreciate the way the exams were organized - they were spaced out well throughout the semester, and the fact that they were not cumulative allowed me to give full focus to the set of modules in question.
I think the class could meet 3 times a week instead of 2. This would allow the classes to be shorter and give students more opportunities to learn the material on a more steady pace.
Professor Yan and the teaching staff were all very wonderful, engaging, and helpful.
It is perfect!!

Strengths: pretty interesting material at the food parts, people present personal recipes that enables you to get to know your classmates better
Weaknesses: a lot of dense chemistry, a lot more chemistry than I expected coming in, lectures are 75 minutes twice a week and there's a discussion section as well

Strengths: Great grading scale
Weaknesses: Hard to stay in engaged in long drawn out lectures
Lot of practice helped learn the material. Also the material wasnt to extensive so was not to hard to comprehend for non-stem majors
Strengths are allowing us to team up with our classmates almost every class to complete questions about what we are learning.

The class was really strong overall (great prof, great TAs, clear expectations and simple content), so I'll just note a few weaknesses here. We had to write a bunch of blog posts over the course of the semester  after the first one, I wasn't really learning that much so it felt just like busy work. Some of the in-class exercises were rushed and less relevant to what we were doing. Also, I think we may have spent a bit too long in breakout rooms debating the merits of Pringles vs. Lays, for instance.
I thought the course was really well organized. The slides used to present the information were extremely clear, and the way in which the information was presented was also very clear.

It was advertised as a science credit for non-STEM majors but after reading week ended, we kind of kept on the theme of food but it just turned more into a gen-chem course which bombards you with psets (that aren't too bad) and course blog commenting that doesn't take too long. However, the assignments due in class were quite a bit during COVID times and due dates and alerts that we even had assignments were not discusses in class. After we preface the chemistry and science with food -- and shopping period ends -- the level of content and topics we cover are a bit in depth and overwhelming!

The broad introduction to chemistry made it accessible to non-stem students, which was a big strength of the course. Maybe because of the virtual format, but I do think the course could have benefited from less breakout rooms or activities in class, as we ended up losing some considerable lecture time. These smaller discussion based activities could ideally be done during the TA discussion sections instead. 
During TA sections, we also had to cover a lot of material not covered in lecture, and I believe changing this to have the material in lecture and activities in section would greatly benefit the learning process.

Strengths: The material was very easy to understand and concepts were clarified very kindly and supportively! I always felt like I was supported or cared for, and I thought Professor Yan was an amazing instructor that genuinely wanted to spread her love for chemistry with others. Weaknesses: PSET questions were hard to complete because some needed to be looked up online, but they weren't denoted as such, so I wasn't sure if I was expected to know the material or not.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were great but the breakout rooms for the exercises were not always successful
The course is wonderful!! I really appreciate how much effort all of the professor, teaching fellows, peer tutors, and others put into making this class such a success!
Breakout room sessions were good ways to engage with classmates during COVID. It  would have been nice to have an asynchronous option, though.
I thought the online class was a success. We could easily go through powerpoints in class and review them with another powerpoint in section.
Lectures were recorded and we were allowed to submit assignments late.
I didn't think there were any issues with taking this course online. I thought that the slides were effective and I was really able to engage with the material.

Not great at telling students we have assignments, cover topics very quickly, sometimes too quickly; though, we don't get tested on the material to the degree in which we engaged the materials, we learned a bunch of other stuff that just was not expected on the test, hindering my personal understanding of the material we should have focused on.

The poll questions were amazing!!! They helped me stay engaged and have small checks of understanding. All lectures were required to be live because of breakout room activities, but I felt like those took up a lot of class time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, specifically a person who wants to get their science credit out of the way with an interesting course that has a great professor and TFs.
Yes if you are looking to fulfill a SC distributional requirement and enjoy cooking
I would recommend this course to any non-STEM majors who need a science credit because it is geared towards you and the lens of food and cooking helps make the content interesting.
Highly recommend for those who are looking for a fun and interesting science credit!! As a non-stem student, I thought the material was very accessible to students of many backgrounds.
The professor was super sweet, smart, and nice.
Yes, I already have recommended this course to many of my friends and colleagues!
I would recommend this course to another student if they like chemistry and food and cooking. The chemistry part is necessary, though.
Absolutely!
Absolutely
Absolutely, the class is helpful for understanding chemistry for a non-stem student.
Yes, to anyone who has no chemistry knowledge.
Yes, because it is a great way to learn chemistry if you do not know it as well as a great grading scale. It is harder than it looks in the syllabus though.
Yes
Yes, I learned valuable lessons in cooking that will definitely be useful. My "why?" questions have been answered.
If you need a science credit, welcome to the Chemistry of Cooking! Dr. Yan's lectures are entertaining and informative and the class is pretty fun overall.

Yes, I think this course was really fun but at the same time you learn a lot. The course taught with an emphasis on how chemistry is related to cooking. This made the content much more enjoyable and it was good context to really understand the concepts.
I'd take a different science credit if you are a non-STEM major seeking a science credit!

Yes, I would recommend this course for non-stem major students who seek a better understanding of chemistry, especially since learning it paired with interesting processes of cooking and understanding food.
YES!!! Great gut course for a science credit, and it's specifically geared towards non-stem majors. I loved the references to food, and even though I was never great at chem, I think I did well!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also weekly discussion sections with our TFs.
Lectures were also recorded if needed and for revision
N/A
Sections
weekly section to supplement the lectures
Live virtual lecture + synchronous section
Lectures were also recorded
virtual lecture paired with discussion/pset sections.
Live virtual lecture and live virtual weekly discussion sections with a TA
Virtual discussion sections, office hours, and review sessions

extras.title:
CHEM 104 01
        Chemistry of Food and Cooking
